Chapter 12: Discrimination of Dependent Origination, part 3, section 12. As such, having explained the differences in the size of the physical world in terms of yojanas, etc., and the differences in the duration of life in terms of years, etc., the two measures are not the same, and what should be explained has not yet been explained.
The establishment of these is not without relying on names. The first two and names have not yet been fully understood. Now, one should first explain the three smallest quantities.
Verse:
The smallest particles of matter, letters, and moments are the smallest units of matter, names, and time.
Treatise:
Using superior wisdom, all matter is analyzed down to the smallest particle. Therefore, the smallest particle is the smallest unit of matter, because it cannot be further divided.
In this way, all names and time are analyzed down to a single letter moment, which is the smallest unit of names and time.
A single-letter name is like saying di (æ‰).
What is the measure of a single moment?
The author of the ÅšÄstra rashly offers this explanation:
When the various conditions come together, dharmas obtain their own nature for a moment.
This explanation is not fully established. We should carefully consider whether the substance of a dharma exists before it arises or not.
The Abhidharma masters say:
When the various conditions come together, dharmas are able to arise, not to obtain their own substance. This is because all dharmas that have not yet arisen already have substance.
If the substance of a dharma already exists, what need is there for it to arise again?

Even though the substance already exists when the various conditions come together, it is able to cause it to reach the state of attracting effects and produce superior function, and therefore it is called arising.
Having reached the present and already arisen, it is able to attract effects. When the ability to attract effects ceases, it is called past. Why is the future unable to attract effects?
This criticism is unreasonable, just as one might criticize the future by asking why it is not called the present.
We say that the ability to attract effects is in the present. Therefore one should not make such a criticism.
Why do you insist on such a tenet?

If it were different from this tenet, whatever was established would be in direct contradiction with innumerable principles and teachings, as will be extensively examined in the chapter on the three times.
Since the principle that the past and future really exist has been established, their assertion of the duration of a moment definitely cannot be reasonable.

Moreover, it is because they depend on other measures to illustrate it. That is to say, when the conditions come together, a dharma obtains its own substance, but it is still not determined how long this dharma lasts.
Moreover, a dharma's moment is not seen in the present world, so when asked what measure is called a moment, one should answer that a moment is of such a measure.
How can they take a moment to illustrate the measure of a moment?
Therefore their explanation is unreasonable.
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas rely on the ultimate truth to say that the measure of a dharma's moment can be indicated by analogy.
However, the Buddha never spoke of it because he saw that no one could understand it.
However, in order to enlighten students, I will use the method of inference to explain it expediently.
It is said that in the time of a strong man snapping his fingers, there are 65 subtle moments.
Thus, the three smallest units have been explained.
The difference between the previous two units will now be explained. What are the measurements of yojanas and so forth?
Verse:
The smallest, subtle, gold, water, rabbit, sheep, ox, dust in the sun,
Lice, barley, finger joint, each subsequent one is seven times larger,
Twenty-four fingers is one cubit, four cubits is one bow-length,
Five hundred bow-lengths is one kroÅ›a, eight kroÅ›as is one yojana.
Commentary:
The size of one subtle atom can also be illustrated, but only the Buddha knows it, so it is not explained.
However, in order to establish the place of seclusion, the Vinaya only says this:
Seven anuÅ›reá¹‡is are one anu. The anu is the first, and the finger joint is the last. You should know that each subsequent one increases sevenfold.

That is, seven anuÅ›reá¹‡is are one anu. Seven anus are one suvará¹‡a-particle. Seven suvará¹‡a-particles are one water-particle. Seven water-particles are one rabbit-fur particle. Seven rabbit-fur particles are one sheep-fur particle. Seven sheep-fur particles are one cow-fur particle. Seven cow-fur particles are one space-traveling particle. Seven space-particles are one louse egg. Seven louse eggs are one louse. Seven lice are one barley grain. Seven barley grains are one finger joint. Three joints are one finger.
This is universally accepted in the world, and therefore it is not specifically distinguished in the verse.
Twenty-four fingers laid out horizontally make one cubit. Four cubits stacked vertically make one bow, which is to say, stacked vertically for five hundred bows makes one kroÅ›a.
The Vinaya says this is the distance from a village to an Äranya.
It is said that eight kroÅ›as make one yojana.
It has been explained how atoms gradually accumulate to form a single yojana.
However, it is accepted that atoms are of two kinds: real and nominal.
What are their characteristics?
The real refers to the self-characteristics of form, etc. that are well-established, which are perceived by direct perception in the state of aggregation;

The nominal is known through analysis and inference. It refers to the distinctions of atoms of form, sound, etc. within aggregated form, which are distinguished through gradually analyzing with wisdom to the utmost, and then discerning them. The atoms reached by this analysis are called nominal atoms, because they cause wisdom to seek and greatly delight.
These atoms are the utmost, therefore they are called atoms.
The utmost refers to the ultimate point reached by analyzing form, while atoms are only the domain of the wisdom-eye. Therefore, the term atoms expresses the meaning of utmost minuteness.
What is the evidence for the existence of atoms?
The evidence is based on the scriptures and reasoning.
As for the scriptures, it refers to the sutras that say:
All forms are either subtle or gross.
The subtle are the most subtle atoms, because they cannot be further divided.
The remaining forms that are resistant are called gross.
There are other masters who explain it like this:

The unwholesome and indeterminate are called gross, and the remaining wholesome forms are called subtle. This is the distinction between the forms of the desire realm and form realm, and between the contaminated and uncontaminated.
This is unreasonable, because the terms inferior and superior already include the distinctions of such natures, etc.
There is another explanation:
The objects of the eye are called gross, and those grasped by the other faculties such as the ear are called subtle.
This is also not good, because both are included in both. Moreover, it is indefinite.
That is to say, there is subtle form like the tip of a hair, which is still difficult to see even for those with extremely clear eyes.
Or there are loud sounds like the sound of thunder, which shakes the heavens and earth and is heard by all who have ears.
Therefore, the term subtle refers to the most subtle form, and the principle is well established.

If you say that a scripture also says that material food has gross and subtle parts, and therefore this explanation is not correct, this is not contradictory, because this scripture speaks of form and that scripture speaks of food, and their intentions are different.
Because one atom can be called form but cannot be called food, therefore the intentions are different, and the principle must be so.
A verse says:
All forms such as black and white have subtle and gross parts.
The subtle ones are called the most minute, and the gross ones are the other resistant ones.
By this true evidence, atoms definitely exist.
And it has been said before.
What was said before?
It is said in the Vinaya:
Seven atoms are called one atom, and so on.
This is the teaching.
What is the principle?
It means that the form of the body of beings, up to the ultimate form, is the grossest.
According to this, it should also be analyzed that there is an ultimate place for all forms, called one atom.
How do we know this?
Because when divisible dharmas are analyzed to the ultimate, there is still remainder.

This is because the world directly perceives that when one aggregate of form is analyzed by another aggregate of form, there is a subtle aggregate that arises. Analyzing and analyzing to the ultimate, there is still a remainder that can be seen by the eye and cannot be further analyzed. In this way, the aggregate of form cannot be analyzed to the point of nonexistence, just as the coarse aggregate has a principle of divisibility.

This means that it can be analyzed by wisdom. Just as when aggregates are analyzed to the ultimate, wisdom analyzing to the ultimate should have a remainder, which can be seen by wisdom and cannot be further analyzed. This remainder is precisely the ultimate atom.
Therefore, the substance of the ultimate atom definitely exists.
If it did not exist, aggregate form would not exist, because aggregate form is necessarily composed of it.
Having explained yojanas and so forth in this way, we should now determine the measure of years and so forth.

One hundred and twenty ká¹£aá¹‡as is the measure of one tatká¹£aá¹‡a,

The treatise says:
One hundred and twenty ká¹£aá¹‡as make one tatká¹£aá¹‡a, sixty tatká¹£aá¹‡as make one lava, thirty lavas make one muhÅ«rta, and thirty muhÅ«rtas make one day and night.
Sometimes the day increases, sometimes it decreases, and sometimes it is equal.
Thirty days and nights make one month, and twelve months make one year.
In one year, it is divided into three seasons, namely cold, hot, and rainy, each with four months.
Among the twelve months, the nights decrease for six months, with the nights decreasing by a total of six in one year.
Why is it so?
Therefore, there is a verse that says:
In the cold, hot, and rainy seasons, half a month has already passed,
In the remaining half month, the wise know the nights decrease.
Thus, having already distinguished the differences in the lengths of moments up to years, we will now explain the differences in the lengths of eons.
Verse:
It should be known that there are four types of eons, namely eons of destruction, formation, duration, and great eons.
The eon of destruction begins when beings are no longer born in the hells and ends when the external environment is completely destroyed.
The eon of formation begins with the arising of wind and ends when beings are first born in the hells.
The middle eon begins with an immeasurable lifespan and ends when the lifespan is only ten years.
Next, it decreases and increases eighteen times, and then increases to eighty thousand.
Thus, after formation, it abides for twenty eons, called the middle eon.
The eon of destruction, the eon of emptiness after destruction, and the eon of formation all last the same as the eon of duration.
Eighty of these middle eons make one great eon. Three of these great eons are called an incalculable eon.
The treatise says:
The eon of destruction refers to the period from when beings no longer take rebirth in the hells until the complete destruction of the external environment.
Destruction is of two kinds: destruction of realms and destruction of destinies.
There are two kinds: destruction of sentient beings and destruction of the external environment.
However, destruction and formation are divided into four periods in general:
1. actual destruction, 2. empty after destruction, 3. actual formation, 4. abiding after formation.

As for actual destruction, it means that after this world has remained for twenty intermediate kalpas, from then on it will remain for twenty more intermediate kalpas, and the kalpa of destruction will arrive.
When the kalpa of destruction is about to begin, the lifespan of humans on this continent is eighty thousand years.

When the lifespan of sentient beings in the hells ends and none are reborn again, it is called the beginning of the kalpa of destruction. Until there is not a single sentient being left in the hells, at that time it is called the hells have been destroyed.
Those who definitely have karma to experience in the hells are drawn by the power of karma to other hells.
Based on this, one can understand the animal and ghost realms.
At that time, there are no worms in the human body, the same as the Buddha's body, because the animal realm has been destroyed.
Some say that the two destinies are beneficial to humans, and that the destruction of humans and non-humans occurs simultaneously, while the destruction of animals occurs first.
Of these two explanations, the former is better.
When in the human realm of this continent, a human being attains the first dhyÄna without a teacher or through natural causes, and upon arising from dhyÄna proclaims:
The joy and pleasure born of separation is very blissful and very tranquil.

When the other humans hear this, they all enter dhyÄna, and upon death they all attain rebirth in the Brahma world. When all the beings of this continent are extinguished, it is called the destruction of the humans of JambudvÄ«pa.
The two continents of the west and north should be explained in the same way.
When the lifespan of the beings of Uttarakuru is exhausted, they are reborn in the desire realm heavens. Because of their dull faculties, they are unable to become free from desire.
After being reborn in the desire realm heavens, the dhyÄna becomes manifest, and they attain a superior basis. Only then are they able to become free from desire.
Until there is not a single sentient being left in the human realm, at that time it is called the destruction of the human realm.

When in the heavens of the desire realm, in any one of the six heavens, by the spontaneous power of the Dharma, one attains the first dhyÄna, and so on, up to all attaining rebirth in the Brahma world, at that time it is called the destruction of the desire heavens.
In this way, there is not a single sentient being in the desire realm, and it is called the destruction of sentient beings in the desire realm.
When in the Brahma world, by the spontaneous power of the Dharma, a single sentient being attains the second dhyÄna, and upon arising from that samÄdhi, proclaims these words:
The joy and pleasure born from samÄdhi is very blissful and very tranquil.

When the other gods hear this, they all enter that samÄdhi, and upon the end of their lives, all attain rebirth in the Ä€bhÄsvara Heaven. Up to the complete extinction of sentient beings in the Brahma world, this is called the destruction of the sentient world, and only the empty and desolate vessel world remains.

The karma of all sentient beings in other world-realms that attracts the existence of this trichiliocosm is exhausted, and then seven suns appear here gradually, drying up the oceans and burning the mountains, the three continents, and the three rings of mountains. The wind blows fierce flames that burn the heavenly palaces up to the palace of BrahmÄ, leaving no trace of ash.

The flames of one's own level burn the palaces of one's own level, and the calamities of other levels cannot destroy other levels. Because they stimulate each other, it is said that the fierce wind below blows and burns the upper levels.
That is to say, the fierce flames of the desire realm rise up and serve as conditions to give rise to the fire of the form realm.

The other calamities are also like this, as should be known according to the circumstances.ğŸ”½In this way, starting from the hells and gradually decreasing, up to the exhaustion of the receptacle world, it is collectively called the eon of destruction.
As for the eon of formation, it refers to the period from the arising of wind up to the first appearance of sentient beings in the hells.

That is, when the world is destroyed by calamity, for twenty intermediate kalpas there is only empty space. After this long period of time, there will again be twenty intermediate kalpas of abiding before the kalpa of creation arrives.
The power of the karma of all sentient beings gradually produces subtle winds in space. This is the first sign of the creation of the external environment.

The winds gradually increase and form the wind wheel, water wheel, and golden wheel as explained above. However, the palaces of the MahÄ-BrahmÄ gods and the YÄma gods are created first, and then the wind wheels, etc. are formed. This is called the creation of the external environment.ğŸ”½The destruction and creation of the environment is due to the power of sentient beings. If sentient beings gather in the upper heavens for a long time, then this external environment will definitely gradually arise, causing those with reduced blessings to scatter and dwell below.

That is, if the sentient beings of the Avá¹›ha heaven gather for a long time, and the number of gods becomes large, their dwelling places will be crowded. Those with reduced blessings should scatter and dwell below.

The reason is that the world must be established first, and then sentient beings are born in it. When the world is destroyed, sentient beings are born in the heaven of the first trance state. When the world is formed, sentient beings are born in the heaven of the second trance state. When the world is destroyed, sentient beings are born in the heaven of the third trance state. When the world is formed, sentient beings are born in the heaven of the fourth trance state. This is the order of the formation and destruction of the world.

When the world is formed, the first sentient being dies in the heaven of the fourth trance state and is born in the palace of the great Brahma heaven.ğŸ”½Later, other sentient beings also die in the heaven of the fourth trance state and are born in the heaven of the second trance state. Some are born in the heaven of the third trance state, some are born in the heaven of the fourth trance state, and some are born in the heaven of the first trance state.

Gradually, they are born in the human realm, in Kuru, GodÄnÄ«ya, Videha, and JambudvÄ«pa. Later, they are born as hungry ghosts, animals, and hell beings. It is the principle that after destruction, formation must occur first.
If the first sentient being is born in AvÄ«ci Hell, the twenty intermediate kalpas of formation should be known to have been completed.
After this, there are again twenty intermediate kalpas called abiding after formation, which occur in sequence.
That is, from the wind, the external world is created, and then sentient beings gradually appear.
The first sentient being to be reborn is the Brahma King of the first trance state, who dies in the Heaven of Great Fruition and is reborn in the palace of the Brahma Heaven.
All Brahma Kings are categorized as ordinary beings, because no saints are reborn in lower realms, and because there are no saints in the two upper realms who enter the path of insight.
For this reason, there is no meaning in the statement that two sentient beings are born in the Brahma Heaven without an interval.

Since it is said that the Brahma King dies last, and the life span of the Heaven of Great Fruition is eight great eons, how can the Brahma King, who is reborn in the Heaven of Great Fruition and has a short life span, die and be reborn in the Heaven of Great Fruition?

Although there is no meaning in the statement that he dies in the middle of his life span, he is born in that heaven because of his vast and great merit. He has only passed through a short period of the eight great eons of his life span. How can he die in the middle of the twenty intermediate eons?
From this we know that the other sentient beings who are reborn here are also like this.

The lifespan of humans in this continent passes through immeasurable time until the beginning of the eon of abiding, when lifespan begins to decrease. From immeasurable, it decreases to a maximum of ten years, which is called the first intermediate eon of abiding.

The next eighteen all have increase and decrease. That is, from ten years it increases to eighty thousand, and then from eighty thousand it decreases back to ten years. This is called the second intermediate eon.
The remaining seventeen are all like this.
After the eighteen, from ten years it increases to a maximum of eighty thousand years, called the twentieth eon.
All increases in eons do not exceed eighty thousand, and all decreases in eons are only to a maximum of ten years.
In the eighteen eons, one increase and one decrease take the same amount of time.
The first decrease and the last increase are the same, so the twenty eons are all of equal duration, which is collectively called the eon of abiding after formation.

The remaining kalpas of creation, of destruction, and of empty time, although they do not have the twenty differences of increase and decrease, are equal to the kalpa of duration in length, and each consists of twenty intermediate kalpas.
In the first intermediate kalpa of creation, the physical world is created; in the remaining nineteen, sentient beings gradually come to be.
In the last intermediate kalpa of destruction, the physical world is destroyed; in the remaining nineteen, sentient beings gradually come to an end.

These twenty intermediate kalpas of creation, duration, destruction, and empty time make eighty, and these eighty make one great kalpa.ğŸ”½If this is so, then in the midst of birth and death, happiness is more than suffering, because the kalpas of destruction, empty time, and creation are exclusively happy.ğŸ”½Although suffering and happiness are mixed in the kalpa of duration, still the time of pure suffering is short and the time of pure happiness is long.
Although this is the case, when suffering arises, it is intense and strong, and this is not so of happiness.
That is, when the body is oppressed by the hot season and the burning sun, even though one uses sandalwood, musk, and ice to alleviate it, there arises a supreme bodily bliss.
At that time, if one is suddenly pricked by a small thorn, one immediately forgets all the pleasures and only feels pain.
In the same way, if one encounters the separation from loved ones, the supreme painful feeling produced in the mind is greater than the pleasure produced by the union with loved ones.
For these reasons, we know that in birth and death, suffering is greater than pleasure, and the principle is certain.
The three eons are only the five aggregates as their essence, because apart from these, the essence of time cannot be found.

The sutra says that one who diligently practices for three incalculable eons attains Buddhahood. Among the four kinds of eons mentioned above, a great eon is accumulated to form three eons without number.
That is to say, from first planting the great bodhi seed, it takes three great eons without number to finally attain the fruit of great bodhi.
Since it is called innumerable, why speak of three again?
Some explain this passage as follows:

The best mathematicians, relying on mathematical treatises, can calculate up to the limit of numbers, but cannot know the first [number], which is called one incalculable. In this way, incalcuables are accumulated to the third.
Others explain it as follows:
Within the sixty numbers, there is a separate number called incalculable. That is, there are sutras that speak of sixty numbers.
This word incalculable corresponds to that one number. Accumulating this to the third is called three incalcuables. It is not that all calculations cannot count and know it.
Bodhisattvas spend these three incalculable eons before finally attaining supreme enlightenment.
Thus, the distinctions in the measure of eons have been explained.
Do Buddhas and Pratyekabuddhas appear in the world during the increase or decrease of eons?
The verse states:
From a decrease of 80,000 to 100 years, Buddhas appear in the world.
Pratyekabuddhas appear during increase and decrease. The rhinoceros-like [Pratyekabuddha] takes 100 eons.
The treatise states:
From the time when the human life span is eighty thousand years, gradually decreasing to the extreme of one hundred years, buddhas appear in the world during this period.
Why do buddhas not appear when the life span is increasing?
Because sentient beings are attached to pleasure and are difficult to teach to become disgusted with it.
Because they often practice good, few fall into the three evil destinies.
Why do buddhas not appear when the life span is decreasing to one hundred years?
Because at that time when the life span is short, they are unable to accomplish what buddhas should do.

That is, all buddhas who appear in the world definitely abandon the fifth part of their life span. They arise from samÄdhi and rely on the body of the life faculty. At that time, those to be converted do not enjoy seeing them. Because even if they appeared in the world, their buddha work would be little. Therefore, at that time, buddhas do not appear in the world.
The author of the treatise explains this as follows:
Because the five impurities are extremely increased and difficult to convert.

Aren't people in this world now decreasing to less than a hundred years? Although the five turbidities are increasing, there are those who can accomplish entering the correct determination, detaching from defilements, and attaining the fruits. The Buddha only appears in the world for these.
Therefore, what they say is not a good explanation.

When the Buddha appears in the world during the period of a hundred years, not all are able to follow the holy teachings, enter the correct determination, detach from defilements, and attain the fruits.
It can be said that in less than a hundred years, one part is not able to accomplish these Buddha-events, so there is no Buddha appearing.

However, even if the Buddha appears in less than a hundred years, there is still one part that is able to follow the teachings, etc., just as when there are a hundred years, why does the Buddha not appear?

If it is said that the Buddha does not appear because the sentient beings who are able to be transformed in less than a hundred years are extremely few, then this should be said: the previously established reason is not able to fully accomplish what the Buddha does.

Although in less than a hundred years, the five turbidities are extremely increased, they are not able to fully accomplish what the Buddha does, and for this reason the Buddha does not appear in the world.
But this direct cause is not what they say.
As for the five turbidities, they are the turbidity of life span, the turbidity of the eon, the turbidity of afflictions, the turbidity of views, and the turbidity of sentient beings.
What is the meaning of turbidity?
Because they are extremely base and inferior, because they should be abandoned, and because they are like dregs and impurities.
Aren't the three turbidities of life span, eon, and sentient beings mutually inseparable? If the turbidity of views is taken as having afflictions as its essence, the five should not be established.
This is indeed reasonable, but it is only to show the five kinds of decline and damage when they are extremely rampant.
What are called the five kinds of decline and damage?
First, the decline and damage of life span, because the time is extremely short;
second, the decline and damage of resources, because they have little luster;
third, the decline and damage of wholesome factors, because they delight in evil conduct;
fourth, the decline and damage of tranquility, because they mutually contradict each other and become noisy;
fifth, the decline and damage of the self-nature, because they are not vessels of supramundane merits.
In order to show the five kinds of decline and damage in different ways, they are divided into five turbidities.
Pratyekabuddhas appear in both long and short eons.
However, there are two kinds of pratyekabuddhas: those who live in groups and those who are like the unicorn.
Those who live in groups were previously Å›rÄvakas who attained the superior fruit and were then called pratyekabuddhas.
Some say that they were originally ordinary beings who had previously cultivated the aids to penetration of the Å›rÄvakas, and now they realize the path on their own and are called pratyekabuddhas.
Because in the main text it is said:
In one mountain there were a total of five hundred ascetic non-Buddhist sages.
There was a monkey who had been close to a pratyekabuddha and saw his dignified demeanor.
It wandered around and came to where the non-Buddhist sages were, displaying the dignified demeanor of the pratyekabuddha it had seen before.
When the sages saw it, they all gave rise to admiration and in an instant all realized pratyekabuddha enlightenment.
If they were originally holy beings, they should not have cultivated ascetic practices.
Those like the unicorn are said to necessarily live alone.
As for pratyekabuddhas, those who are like rhinoceroses must cultivate the requisites for bodhi for a hundred great eons, after which they then become pratyekabuddhas who are like rhinoceroses.

As for pratyekabuddhas, it means that in their present bodies they are free from receiving the ultimate teaching, and they only awaken to the path by themselves, because they are able to regulate themselves but not regulate others.
Why is it said that pratyekabuddhas do not regulate others?
It is not that they are unable to expound the true Dharma, because they also attain unobstructed understanding.

Moreover, they are able to recollect the words of the buddhas that they have heard in the past, and are able to expound them for others, because they attain the cognition of past abodes that can reach the most distant objects.
Moreover, it cannot be said that they lack compassion, because they manifest spiritual powers in order to gather sentient beings.

Moreover, it cannot be said that there are no receptive faculties for receiving the teaching, because at that time sentient beings are also able to give rise to the path of practice that is a counteragent to the worldly detachment.
Although there is this principle, it is now being measured.

At that time, sentient beings' faculties and desires are known, and they enter the truth of the path, etc., without relying on the teachings of others. Therefore, they do not speak the Dharma to tame others.
Except for this, in the remaining matters of gathering sentient beings, there is no need to establish teachings. By manifesting spiritual powers, they are accomplished.

Moreover, solitary realizers lack the powers and fearlessnesses. In the midst of those who firmly grasp onto the doctrine of self, they wish to speak of non-self, but their minds become timid and inferior. Therefore, they do not speak the teachings to tame others.
Some other masters say:
Because solitary realizers have long cultivated the superior understanding of few desires, and also avoid the faults of the clamor of gathering crowds, they do not speak the Dharma to tame others.
If they have the ability themselves and others have faculties and desires, to abandon them and not save and liberate them, how can they be called compassionate?
Therefore, the previous explanation is better.
In what time does a wheel-turning king appear in the world?
How many kinds, how many together, what authority, what characteristics?
The verse says:
Wheel-turning kings have lifespans of 80,000 years or more. They have golden, silver, copper, and iron wheels.
One, two, three, or four continents, in reverse order, alone like the Buddha.
Others welcome him, he goes himself to subdue, in disputes and battles he is victorious without harm,
his appearance is not correct, bright and round, therefore he is not equal to the Buddha.
The treatise says:
From this continent, when the lifespan of humans is immeasurable years up to 80,000 years, there are wheel-turning kings born.
When it decreases to 80,000 years, sentient beings' wealth and happiness and lifespan decrease, because they are not suitable vessels.
Or because the karma that accords with their experience definitely gives results at that time and place.
Just as the karma that results in a Buddha's body can only give results when the eon is decreasing.
The king, due to the precious wheel, turns and leads, and his majesty subdues all, and is called a wheel-turning king.

In the Abhidharma-nyÄyÃ¢nusÄra, it is said there are four kinds, gold, silver, copper, and iron, because the wheels should be distinguished. In reverse order, they rule over one, two, three, or four continents, respectively.
That is, a king with iron wheels rules one continent, a king with copper wheels rules two, a king with silver wheels rules three, and a king with gold wheels rules the four continents.
The scriptures, in speaking of the superiority of the wheel-turning king, only speak of the golden wheel. Thus a scripture says:

If a king is born in the ká¹£atriya class, ascends the throne, on the fifteenth day of the month observes the precepts, bathes his head and body, receives the superior precepts, ascends to the high palace, with his ministers and officials at his side, suddenly in the east there appears a golden wheel treasure with a thousand spokes, complete with hub and rim, its myriad characteristics round and pure, not made by an artisan, emitting wondrous light, coming to respond to the king.
